questions.text: You are an intern of ophthalmology OPD, one patient was diagnosed with pars planitis on slit lamp examination which cannot be noticed in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Snowball opacities Snowball opacities are not appreciated on slit lamp examination. These are best seen with indirect ophthalmoscopy and Goldman's three-mirror examination. Posterior segment signs ( pathognomic of intermediate uveitis) are: Vitreous Cells (+l to+4), Anterior vitreous condensation, Snowball or cotton ball opacities (Ant's eggs) refer to typical exudates present near the ora serrata in the inferior quadrant. Snow banking, e. grey white fibrovascular plaque over the pars plana with or without associated peripheral retinal periphlebitis forms the hallmark of intermediate uveitis. It is formed due to the coalescence of snowball opacities . These are best seen with indirect ophthalmoscopy and Goldman's three-mirror examination.

INTERMEDIATE UVEITIS Intermediate uveitis refers to inflammation involving pars plana ciliaris, peripheral retina, choroid and vitreous base. Epidemiology Accounts for 10% of all cases of uveitis and 20% of cases of uveitis in children, • Bilateral in 80% of cases, • Males and females are equally affected, • Age: onset typically in 2nd and 4th decade (bimodal). Etiology Idiopathic in about 85% of cases. Immunogenic predisposition is reported with a positive correlation with HLA-DR2. Known causes (15% cases) include tuberculosis, syphilis, sarcoidosis, Lyme disease, and multiple sclerosis. Clinical features Symptoms Asymptomatic in many cases, Floaters of insidious onset are the most common presentation , Blurring of vision and decreased vision may occur later, Pain, photophobia, and redness are conspicuously absent. Signs Anterior segment signs. Low-grade flare and cells, Few KPs due to spillover anterior uveitis, Lens may show complicated cataracts in late stages. Posterior segment signs pathognomic of intermediate uveitis Vitreous Cells (+l to+4), Anterior vitreous condensation, Snowball or cotton ball opacities (Ant's eggs) refer to typical exudates present near the ora serrata in the inferior quadrant. Snow banking, e. grey white fibrovascular plaque over the pars plana with or without associated peripheral retinal periphlebitis forms the hallmark of intermediate uveitis. It is formed due to the coalescence of snowball opacities . These are best seen with indirect ophthalmoscopy and Goldman three mirror examination Course and prognosis . Relatively good prognosis if well treated. The course is usually chronic with three distinct patterns: Single, mild self-limiting episode (10%) cases, Prolonged course without exacerbations (60% cases), and Chronic smoldering course with multiple sub-acute exacerbations (30% cases). Complications include Complicated cataracts, cystoid macular edema, band keratopathy, secondary glaucoma, vitreous hemorrhage, and tractional retinal detachment. Treatment : Step 1 : Periocular And Systemic Steroids. Topical steroids are not of much use. • Posterior subtenon. injection of triamcinolone 40 mg/3 weeks x 3 injections are indicated initially. • Systemic steroids are given in unresponsive cases. Step 2: Immunosuppressive drugs such as cyclosporine, azathioprine, methotrexate, or cyclophosphamide should be given with careful monitoring of effects and potential side effects when step l measures fail. Step 3 : Cryotherapy or indirect laser photocoagulation should be tried in cases with snow banking. Step 4 : Pars-plana vitrectomy is indicated in severe cases and when step 3 measures fail. It helps by removing inflammatory debris, antigenic load, and possible traction on the macula. Its role in tractional RD is unequivocal.

questions.text: One 50 yrs old male patient presented in OPD with complaints of seeing black spots In Front of the eye and dimness of vision on Fundus examination with indirect ophthalmoscope reveals this picture Identify the image?

options.label: A
options.text: Snow banking- settle down exudates in vitreous

options.label: B
options.text: Snowball opacities -clumps of exudates in vitreous

options.label: C
options.text: Snow-storm opacities - clumps of exudates in vitreous

options.label: D
options.text: Snowflake opacities- clumps of exudates in vitreous

questions.correct_answer: B. Snowball opacities -clumps of exudates in vitreous
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Snowball opacities -clumps of exudates in vitreous Fundus examination with an indirect ophthalmoscope reveals the whitish exudates present near the ora serrata in the inferior quadrant. These typical exudates are referred to as snowball opacities. These may coalesce to form a grey-white plaque called snow banking.

Snowflake cataract: These cataracts can present in young individuals with diabetes mellitus due to high blood sugar (hyperglycemia) . They appear as snowflake-shaped opacities in the outer layer (cortex) of the lens.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy from a rural area was referred for a one-month history of painless blurry vision and floaters in the right eye. His past medical history was statistically significant for recurrent group A Streptococcus infection of the pharynx with an increased titer of ASO antibodies, recurrent mouth sores, and headaches. You found visual acuities of 15/50 and 20/25, and intraocular pressures of 18 and 16 mmHg right and left eye, respectively. The slit lamp examination revealed 3+ cells in the anterior chamber OD and 1.5+ cells in the anterior chamber OS. Ophthalmoscopy disclosed 3+ cells in the vitreous OD, 1+ cells in the vitreous OS, and exudate with blurred margins in the pars plana between 3 and 9 o'clock. What is your provisional diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intermediate Uveitis The slit lamp examination revealed 3+ cells in the anterior chamber OD and 1.5+ cells in the anterior chamber OS. Ophthalmoscopy disclosed 3+ cells in the vitreous OD, 1+ cells in the vitreous OS, and exudate with blurred margins in the pars plana between 3 and 9 o'clock suggestive of pars planitis.
